title: 106_hr3373
content:
The Leif Ericson Millennium Commemorative Coin Act is the short title for Title I. Coin specifications are outlined in Section 102. SEC. 102 of the Leif Ericson Millennium Commemorative Coin Act specifies the coin specifications for $1 silver coins minted in commemoration of the millennium of Leif Ericson's discovery of the New World. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary can obtain silver for minting coins from any available source, including stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. SEC. 104. DESIGN OF COINS. The coins minted under this title shall symbolize the millennium of Leif Ericson's discovery of the New World. Each coin will display the coin's value, the year "2000", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Leifur Eiriksson Foundation and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee.

SEC. 105. ISSUANCE OF COINS. SEC. 105. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this title shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Only one facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular quality of the coins minted under this title. The Secretary may issue coins minted under this title beginning January 1, 2000, and no coins may be minted after December 31, 2000. SEC. 106. SURCHARGES. Sales of coins minted under this title include a $10 surcharge per coin, with proceeds going to the Leifur Eiriksson Foundation for student exchanges between US and Icelandic students. The Foundation is subject to audit requirements. SEC. 107. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. TITLE II--CAPITOL VISITOR CENTER COMMEMORATIVE COIN

SEC. 107. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this title, except for equal employment opportunity laws. Congress acknowledges the historical significance of the Capitol building, its importance as a symbol of democracy, the need for improved visitor facilities, the dedication of the Capitol Police for security, and the funding allocated for the construction of the Capitol Visitor Center. Congress wants to allow voluntary fundraising for the Capitol Visitor Center and authorize coins to commemorate the first Congress meeting in the Capitol building, with proceeds going towards preservation efforts. SEC. 203. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue various coins under this title, including bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific specifications. Additionally, the Secretary may mint $5 gold coins if deemed necessary. The Secretary may mint up to 100,000 $5 gold coins weighing 8.359 grams, with a diameter of 0.850 inches, containing 90% gold and 10% alloy. These coins are legal tender as per section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 204. The Secretary will obtain platinum and gold from available sources for minting coins. Silver may be obtained from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. SEC. 205. The design of coins will be determined. SEC. 205. Design of coins emblematic of the first meeting of the United States Congress in the United States Capitol Building, with specific inscriptions and design selection process involving various committees and commissions. SEC. 206. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this title in uncirculated and proof qualities, must bear the year "2001" and be struck at a designated US Mint facility. The Secretary must consult with the Commission for promotion and marketing of these coins, potentially entering into a contract for assistance. The Secretary may enter into a contract with the Commission or an entity to carry out a specific role. SEC. 207. SALE OF COINS. The coins minted under this title will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Surcharges will be included in all sales. The Secretary will establish surcharges for the $10, $5, $1, and half dollar coins, ranging from $3 to $50 per coin. SEC. 208. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will go to the Capitol Preservation Fund for the Capitol Visitor Center. TITLE III--LEWIS AND CLARK EXPEDITION COMMEMORATIVE COIN. This title is known as the Lewis and Clark Expedition Bicentennial Commemorative Coin Act. The Congress recognizes the significant achievements of the Lewis and Clark Expedition, also known as "The Corps of Discovery", in advancing geographical knowledge of the continent and facilitating trade with American Indian tribes. President Thomas Jefferson tasked Lewis and Clark with exploring the Missouri River and finding a practical water route to the Pacific Ocean for commerce purposes. The Lewis and Clark Expedition, also known as "The Corps of Discovery", was directed by President Jefferson to explore the newly acquired Louisiana territory and record natural resources. The Expedition departed from St. Louis, Missouri in May 1804, met with American Indians at Council Bluff, wintered at Fort Mandan, crossed the Rocky Mountains, and returned to St. Louis in September 1806 after covering 8,000 miles and traversing 11 future States. The Lewis and Clark Expedition traversed 11 future States, enhancing knowledge of the western continent and fostering friendly relationships with American Indian nations. It has been hailed as the most perfect expedition of its kind in history, paving the way for the United States to become a great world power. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 500,000 $1 coins commemorating the Lewis and Clark Expedition. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary can obtain silver for minting from various sources, including stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. SEC. 305. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this title shall be emblematic of the expedition of Lewis and Clark, with inscriptions of the coin value, year, and key words. The obverse of each coin will feature Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, with elements from the Jefferson Peace and Friendship Medal considered in the design. The design for the coins minted under this title shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 306. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this title shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single Mint facility from January 1, 2004, to December 31, 2004. SEC. 307. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 307. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this title will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, plus a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. SEC. 308. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Proceeds from surcharges on coins sold under this title will be divided with two-thirds going to the National Lewis and Clark Bicentennial Council and one-third to the National Park Service for activities related to commemorating the Lewis and Clark Expedition. Recipients of these funds will be subject to audit requirements. SEC. 309. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 309. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the government when minting coins. Payment for coins must be received in full, with security or guarantee for indemnification.
